awd_titl_txt: High Performance Polymer Electrolytes through High Dielectric Polymers and Blends
awd_abstract_narration:
High capacity batteries are key to increasing the range and performance of sustainable transportation technologies. The use of polymer electrolytes is a promising strategy to increase the capacity and safety of lithium batteries. This combined theoretical and experimental project will fill the gaps in fundamental understanding of ion conduction in pure polymers and their blends to improve performance for real-world applications. A polymer blending strategy enables the combination of favorable characteristics at blend compositions that maximize electrolyte performance. The combined use of theory and experiment in this project increases the efficiency of discovery, the depth of fundamental understanding, and speeds progress on this economically and environmentally important field of research in energy storage. The results of the proposed fundamental research will be directly applicable to development of more efficiently conducting polymer electrolytes for deployment in lithium batteries. Such advances can potentially impact applications as diverse as cellphone batteries, development of electric cars, and large scale grid storage. To complement the research efforts, the PIs will carry out educational and outreach activities. These will include graduate and undergraduate student research initiatives aimed at synergistic theoretical-experimental activities, the development of a new educational module on polymer electrolytes and sustainable energy resources, and outreach efforts on sustainable energy and batteries that are directed towards K-12 audiences.

Given the advantages of polymer electrolytes in the context of lithium batteries, the continuing challenge for macromolecular electrolytes has been to increase ionic conductivity. The project will present new concepts which motivate the design of new materials that would both advance fundamental understanding of polymer electrolytes and enable appreciable improvements in storage capacity. The overall hypothesis of the research program is predicated on the observation that ionic conductivity in a homologous series of polyethers was shown to depend primarily on the dielectric constant and not glass-transition temperature or viscosity of the parent polymer. Significantly, this suggested the hypothesis that there could be parametric regimes or classes of polymeric materials in which the transport of ions is only limited by the solubility and dissociation of the ions themselves, and that further increases in ionic conductivity would be possible by enhancing the inherent dielectric constant of the material. Ultimately, increases in dielectric constant may be accompanied by an increase in the glass-transition temperature and that the resulting slow segmental dynamics of the polymer will hinder ion conduction. The project includes study of blends of high-dielectric polymeric materials with low-viscosity analogs to achieve further enhancement in ion conductivities not limited by polymer segmental dynamics. The ultimate result of the integrated study on ion transport in polymer materials will identify the importance of the polymer dielectric constant upon ion conductivities, and provide a new quantitative understanding of ion transport as a function of polymer properties. Furthermore, the research will exploit the non-ideal conductivity characteristics of blends that will lead to a new understanding of the conductivity characteristics of polymer mixtures and may unite the understanding of ion transport in polymer electrolytes with those of small molecule electrolytes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The field of polymer electrolytes for lithium ion batteries was revolutionized around 40 years ago by the discovery of ionic conductivity of poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) complexes with alkali metal salts. In this project, we presented and explored hypotheses which motivated the development of new materials that advanced fundamental understanding of the limitations of ionic conductivity in polymer electrolytes. The overall vision of the proposed research program was predicated on the observation that ionic conductivity in a homologous series of polyethers was shown only to depend on the dielectric constant and not segmental dynamics of the parent polymer. Significantly, this suggested the hypothesis that there could be parametric regimes or classes of polymeric materials in which the transport of ions is only limited by the solubility and dissociation of the ions themselves, and that further increases in ionic conductivity would be possible by enhancing the inherent dielectric constant of the material. Such a hypothesis formed the basis for our collaborative research, which explored the synthesis and concomitant computer simulations of a range of high dielectric polymers.

Intellectual Merit:

Much of the present and past research efforts on polymer electrolytes have derived from the belief that polymer segmental dynamics are the limiting characteristic of ion conductivity. The result of our proposed integrated study on ion transport in polymer materials provided a new paradigm and identified the importance of the polymer dielectric constant on ionic conductivities and segmental dynamics of neutral polymer electrolyte hosts. The results point to future directions for polymer electrolyte research.

Broader Impacts:

The results of the proposed research are directly applicable to development of more efficient conducting polymer electrolytes for deployment in lithium ion batteries. Such advances can potentially impact applications as diverse as cellphone batteries, development of electric cars and larger scale grid storage of energy. To complement our research efforts, the investigators carried out complementary educational and outreach activities. This included graduate and undergraduate student research initiatives aimed at synergistic theoretical-experimental activities, and the development of new educational modules on polymer electrolytes and sustainable energy resources.

Selected Publications:

Keith, Jordan R., Santosh Mogurampelly, Faisal Aldukhi, Bill K. Wheatle, and Venkat Ganesan. "Influence of Molecular Weight on Ion-Transport Properties of Polymeric Ionic Liquids." Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics 19, no. 43 (2017): 29134–45.

Wheatle, Bill K., Jordan R. Keith, Santosh Mogurampelly, Nathaniel A. Lynd, and Venkat Ganesan. "Influence of Dielectric Constant on Ionic Transport in Polyether-Based Electrolytes." ACS Macro Letters 6, no. 12 (December 19, 2017): 1362–67.

Wheatle, Bill K., Jordan R. Keith, Santosh Mogurampelly, Nathaniel A. Lynd, and Venkat Ganesan. "Influence of Dielectric Constant on Ionic Transport in Polyether-Based Electrolytes." ACS Macro Letters 6, no. 12 (December 19, 2017): 1362–67.

Wheatle, Bill K., Nathaniel A. Lynd, and Venkat Ganesan. "Effect of Polymer Polarity on Ion Transport: A Competition between Ion Aggregation and Polymer Segmental Dynamics." ACS Macro Letters 7, no. 10 (October 16, 2018): 1149-54.

Wheatle, Bill K., Erick F. Fuentes, Nathaniel A. Lynd, and Venkat Ganesan. "Influence of Host Polarity on Correlating Salt Concentration, Molecular Weight, and Molar Conductivity in Polymer Electrolytes." ACS Macro Letters 8, no. 8 (August 20, 2019): 888–92.

Wheatle, Bill K., Nathaniel A. Lynd, and Venkat Ganesan. "Effect of Host Incompatibility and Polarity Contrast on Ion Transport in Ternary Polymer-Polymer-Salt Blend Electrolytes." Macromolecules 53, no. 3 (February 11, 2020): 875–84.

Bentley, Caitlin L., Malgorzata Chwatko, Bill K. Wheatle, Aaron A. Burkey, Alysha Helenic, Oscar Morales-Collazo, Venkat Ganesan, Nathaniel A. Lynd, and Joan F. Brennecke. "Modes of Interaction in Binary Blends of Hydrophobic Polyethers and Imidazolium Bis(Trifluoromethylsulfonyl)Imide Ionic Liquids." Macromolecules 53, no. 15 (August 11, 2020): 6519–28.

Wheatle, Bill K., Erick F. Fuentes, Nathaniel A. Lynd, and Venkat Ganesan. "Design of Polymer Blend Electrolytes through a Machine Learning Approach." Macromolecules 53, no. 21 (November 10, 2020): 9449–59.

Keith, Jordan R., and Venkat Ganesan. "Ion Transport Mechanisms in Salt‐doped Polymerized Zwitterionic Electrolytes." Journal of Polymer Science 58, no. 4 (February 15, 2020): 578–88.

Imbrogno, Jennifer, Kazuya Maruyama, Frederick Rivers, Jacob R. Baltzegar, Zidan Zhang, Paul W. Meyer, Venkat Ganesan, Sadahito Aoshima, and Nathaniel A. Lynd. "Relationship between Ionic Conductivity, Glass Transition Temperature, and Dielectric Constant in Poly(Vinyl Ether) Lithium Electrolytes.? ACS Macro Letters 10, no. 8 (August 17, 2021): 1002–7.

Pedretti, Benjamin J., Natalie J. Czarnecki, Congzhi Zhu, Jennifer Imrbogno, Frederick Rivers, Benny D. Freeman, Venkat Ganesan, and Nathaniel A. Lynd. "Structure-Property Relationships for Polyether-Based Electrolytes in the High-Dielectric Constant Regime." Under Revision. 2022.

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2022
Modified by: Nathaniel Lynd
